title.narrative: Yemen Peace Forum

description.narrative: A track II youth and civil society platform facilitated by the Sana’a Center. This interactive initiative seeks to both invest in building and empowering the next generation of Yemeni youth and civil society actors and to engage them in critical national issues. Building on the Sana’a Center’s core goal of producing knowledge by local voices, this initiative seeks to develop and invest in young policy analysts and writers across Yemen. Through this two-year initiative, the Center will build the capacity of dozens of youth and civil society representatives from across Yemen focusing on key topics and regions. Capitalizing on its strong network, the Sana’a Center will also create various platforms and hubs for national and marginalized local voices and initiatives in Yemen and the diaspora to influence policies and shape narratives at all levels. To influence policy- and decision-making, the Center will link these groups and their peacebuilding efforts with the UN-led peace process, political processes, local, regional, and international stakeholders, and the media.

The overall goal of the Yemen Peace Forum is to expand the participation of Yemeni youth and civil society, including women, in the peacemaking process, to build their policy analysis, writing and communication skills and reactivate their political role domestically and internationally. The project will work to achieve this goal by : ● Building a platform for community groups to collaborate on national issues, define peace and engage in peacebuilding and the peacemaking process. ● Equipping youth activists and civil society representatives, focusing on CSOs, with the tools to produce knowledge and conduct international advocacy about Yemeni issues from a grassroots perspective. ● Facilitating access for youth and civil society to inform, engage, influence and build relationships with international stakeholders, policymakers and donors and the media. ● Mobilizing the voices of youth and civil society to inform and influence the UN and international peace processes. ● Informing and engaging the international community on Yemeni issues from a grassroots and youth perspective to facilitate a more responsive, inclusive approach to Yemen and the peace process. ● Building local youth and civil society buy in for the UN-led peace process.

activity-date.narrative: The effective start of this activity is in 11 November, 2019

recipient-country.narrative: This project is completely to be implemented in Yemen only.

title.narrative: YPF Final Report Oct 2019 - Nov 2021

With support and guidance from Saferworld the Sana'a Center will be able to report according to IATI. And the policies of the Sana'a Center will be finalized, and a new strategic vision will be developed.
Final policy documents and quality of financial and administrative reports.

description.narrative: Three policy have been finished which are code of conduct , Whistleblowing policy , Harassment and bullying prevention policy. Recruitment and Selection , Employment contracts , Remuneration and benefits , Leaves , Staff Performance , Learning and development , Disciplinary action , Termination of Employment , Anti-Corruption Policy , Confidentiality and Proprietary Information"NDA" , Conflict of Interest , Grievance Policy are in last stages of internal approval and finalisation including

title.narrative: The most critical issues to work on will be identified in the first workshop and will be the baseline for the on-ground consultations with other peer CSOs. Another workshop will be held and an outreach and advocacy plan will be developed and crafted to link civil society representatives with international organizations and to engage them to more local organizations.
3 in-person meetings 1 statement for each workshop

comment.narrative: One in person meeting was held in Sana'a in February 2020, though no statement was released for security reasons of the participants. Another meeting was held in July 2021 in Mukalla

title.narrative: Up to 5 stories were reported in local and international media outlet.

comment.narrative: The stories have been pitched to international media outlets. One of them was published on the New Arab website by Aisha Al-Jaeadi, a youth delegate from YPF who wrote an article about the experience of being a Muallad in Hadrami society. Two more stories were published on the Sana'a center website.

title.narrative: Up to 50 civil society representatives are engaged through consultation meetings with Yemen Peace Network Representatives.

location.ref: YPF non- governmental organizations gathered more than 50 civil society representatives all around Yemen. These consultations discussed issues based on pre-developed questions, which were designed to fit all governorates. They focus on different aspects such as: the role of youth and NGOs; the role of the UN Special Envoy’s office; the impact of war on the work of NGOs and youth activism; the impact of war on the most vulnerable individuals; the effects of war on art and cultural activities; and opportunities and obstacles to peace process.

title.narrative: The institutional policies of the Sana'a Center will be reviewed, including financial and administrative policies, and the performance of the Sana'a Center team will be enhanced, through grant management and programmatic support including the support on reporting by IATI.
Number of meetings with the Saferworld experts

comment.narrative: Seven meetings have been held between the management of the Sana'a Center and SaferWorld to develop the institutional policies.

title.narrative: Sana’a Center reporting through IATI system

comment.narrative: Two support sessions on IATI were provided to the management of the Yemen Peace Forum project.

location.ref: 3 Meeting have been held to discuss the HR policies, institutional development for our EU/US offices, and security policies. Respective documents are being reviewed

title.narrative: Financial strategy developed, and M&E plan and processes developed.

comment.narrative: Two meetings were held to discuss the financial strategy and the M&E plan for the YPF project and the center.

title.narrative: The perspectives and insights of youth and civil society on the peace process and current issues, and their visions for peace will be shared through meetings with the UN Special Envoy's office, publications (20 produced by the project participants on local issues), and policy briefs (4 produced by the Sana'a Center on the process and engagement of youth and civil society).
20 publications published and shared

location.ref: 1 article was published reflecting the history and status of Cinema in Yemen. Another 4 writings are were published one about the deteriorating status of the Old city of Sana'a and another story about small business in Mukalla and the obstacles they face and how the authorities should support, the protest in Mukalla city and the situation of old Sana'a. One policy brief was published about the situation of women with Covid 19

2 writings were published successfully. One about a personal journey that led to the start of an organization to help amputees and provide prosthetics and physical therapy for them in the midst of the Yemen war. The other is, a personal narrative where in the writer recounts the ordeal of getting her car filled with gas in Sanaa, the fuel shortage, the black market and the long queue sufferings. The drafts are being edited and will be published in March 2021. - In addition, drafts of 2 other writings about Old Sana’a and Cinema in Aden have been submitted to the editorial team and they will be published early in April 2021. - 7 policy brief proposals were approved, and researchers have started collecting the data and some are in the last stages of analysis. These policy briefs will be published during the period between June-September 2021. They reflect issues of importance to Yemeni communities, local actors, and different society levels.

4 publications including personal narratives, stories, essays and reports that discuss local issues are ready for publication. 3 other policy briefs are on the pipeline, proposals have been approved and researchers started collecting information.

The YPF participants and fellows applied the knowledge and skills they gained from the trainings and capacity building on research methodology,, With close mentoring from their mentors, they were able to present several important topics in their writings following an evidence based approach. The project brought 9 publications during this stage some were published which are 1- IDPs in Hudaydah , 2- Curriculum changes to mold the Jihadis of tomorrow , 3- Sanitation in Al-Mahra 4- Has Riyadh woken up from Its Al-Mahra pipe dream . And some are in the last stages of internal processes for publication. ,The papers are on the following topics: 1-Other side of Aden , 2- Cooking gaz in Taiz ,3- Civil society in Marib , 4- Social Fragmentation and Restoration in Taiz , 5- Civil engagement model .

title.narrative: Up to 2 meetings between the Yemen Peace Network and INGO representatives.

location.ref: 5 members, 3 of the Yemen Peace forum and 2 of the Youth Peace network were invited to present their activism and social work to International organizations during the Yemen exchange event that the Sana'a Center held twice in 2020. In Addition to that 2 other youth delegates were featured as key speakers in an online discussion with UK Minister for the Middle East and North Africa James Cleverly hosted by the UK's FCDO and Save the children. Furthermore a discussion panel was conducted between the YPF youth and Geneva graduate institute on the week of Peace. And another virtual event featured two youth representatives as key speakers with the the Netherlands ambassador to Yemen and Yemen ambassador to the Netherlands with attendees from variant European country missions and UN envoy office.

title.narrative: 4 in-person meetings between the Yemen Youth Network and the Yemen Peace Network and the UN envoy or his senior team.

location.ref: Due to the limitations of travel in the times of Covid-19. One meeting was held online between the Yemen Youth Network and the Yemen Peace Network and the UN envoy senior team. Another meeting took place in May 25 where the UN envoy office attended and discuss with two youth representatives the issues of youth and their insights to the peace process. One meeting was held in Mukalla with the youth and CSOs representatives where they met virtually with with the Head of the Political Affairs Department of the Office of the Special Envoy to Yemen Marwan Ali. The fourth YPF in person meeting was held in Amman - Jordan. This meeting brought together about 16 civil society representatives and 13 youth activists from different governorates of Yemen. This activity included different aspects; Capacity building and multiple discussions of societal issues, selecting a priority issue to advocate for, conducting an extensive meeting with representatives of the international community, reviewing societal issues that young people worked on, and reviewing solutions and recommendations from their point of view .The 13 youth had a separate meeting with 3 OSESGY representatives in Amman. The youth presented issues they prioritized , particularly, regarding youth participation in the peace process.

title.narrative: Youth will have identified a joint mechanism to advocate for youth-related issues in the peacemaking and post-conflict political process. Youth will develop a clear vision and agenda to support the efforts of the peacemaking process, and more youth across Yemen will be engaged and connected to the Yemen Youth Network.
Up to 100 youth are engaged through the consultation meetings to be held by the Yemen Youth Network

location.ref: Yemen Youth network engaged more than 100 youth from all around Yemen and outside. The consultations discussed various issues based on pre-developed questions, which were designed to fit all governorates. They focus on different aspects such as: the role of youth and NGOs; the role of the UN Special Envoy’s office; the impact of war on the work of NGOs and youth activism; the impact of war on the most vulnerable individuals; the effects of war on art and cultural activities; and opportunities and obstacles to peace process.

title.narrative: 2 youth representatives will attend the peace talks ( depending on UN facilitation).
1 press statement released after each meeting
A Yemen Youth Network will be established as a youth track II initiative similar to the women’s alliance supported by the UN, and two workshops will be held outside of Yemen.
12 youth representatives are equipped with advocacy and communication skills

A Yemen Peace Forum will be formed of civil society representatives as a platform for grassroots concerns and issues. Up to 18 participants’ capacities will be built in policy communications, international advocacy and message development and the platform will engage directly with international organisations and the peacemaking process.
3 in-person meetings 1 statement for each workshop.
13 civil society representatives will be equipped with policy and advocacy skills

Meetings will be held between the Yemen Peace Forum and the Yemen Youth Network with the UN Special Envoy’s office, diplomats, government officials, other stakeholders and journalists to discuss critical national issues and the peace process.
Up to 10 media outlets engaged with the work of Yemen Peace Network and Yemen Youth Network
